content.title: The Verification Workflow
content.content:
### In this lesson
This lesson teaches the high-level workflow required to confirm a new system is ready for use. You will learn how to organize the transition from a finished installation to a functional one through a structured hierarchy. Key takeaways include the definition of initial verification, the necessity of visual checks before physical testing, and the mandatory chronological order of the testing sequence.

**What this is**
**Initial Verification** is the systematic process of inspecting and testing an installation before it is put into service to ensure it is safe and meets required standards. It is not a random check; it is a formal, documented process that validates the quality of the work performed. This process is divided into two main phases: the **Visual Inspection** and the **Sequence of Tests**. The **Visual Inspection** is the preliminary check of an installation for damage or non-compliance using the senses, which must be completed before any physical testing begins. Once the system passes the visual check, it moves into **Dead Testing**, which is a series of electrical measurements performed while the installation is disconnected from the power supply. This phase eliminates the risk of electric shock during the process and ensures that the fundamental structure of the installation is sound.

**Why it matters**
Following a structured workflow ensures that safety is built into the process rather than added as an afterthought. By conducting **Initial Verification**, a technician identifies faults that could lead to fire or injury before the system is ever energized. The **Sequence of Tests** is particularly critical because it follows a logical path where each result provides the foundation for the next. For example, you must confirm a path is continuous before you can test if its insulation is effective. Skipping steps or performing them out of order can lead to false readings or, in many cases, damage to the equipment being tested.

**Key facts / rules**
*   **Initial Verification** typically occurs only on new installations or significant additions.
*   **Visual Inspection** must always precede physical testing to identify obvious hazards.
*   The **Sequence of Tests** is a mandatory chronological order that ensures safety and accuracy.
*   **Dead Testing** is the primary method used during this phase to maintain a zero-voltage environment.
*   All results must be recorded on the appropriate industry-standard documentation.
*   A failure in any part of the sequence requires a stop to investigate and repair before continuing.

**When to choose it**
Technicians choose this workflow at the completion of a project or after major modifications. You apply **Initial Verification** when you need to provide a legal and technical guarantee that the work meets safety regulations. It is chosen specifically before the system is connected to a live supply. If a technician is presented with a completed installation and asked to "turn it on," they must instead choose to perform the full **Sequence of Tests** first. For example, if a circuit has a measurement of 0.1 ohms in the first test but requires a value below 0.5 ohms to pass, the technician confirms it is safe to proceed to the next test in the sequence.

**Common mistakes**
Learners often confuse **Initial Verification** with periodic maintenance; **Initial Verification** is a comprehensive check for new work before service, whereas periodic maintenance is a recurring check on existing systems. Another common error is attempting to perform testing before the **Visual Inspection** is complete, which can lead to testing a circuit that has visible, dangerous defects.

Misconceptions (targeted):
* Misconception: You can perform tests in any order as long as they all get done. | Correction: The **Sequence of Tests** is a mandatory chronological order where each test relies on the safety established by the previous one. | AC: AC1
* Misconception: **Visual Inspection** is just a quick look-over. | Correction: It is a formal, sensory check that must be documented and completed before any instruments are used. | AC: AC3

**Key Points**
*   **Initial Verification** is a mandatory process for all new installations.
*   The **Visual Inspection** is the first step and relies on sight, touch, and smell.
*   **Dead Testing** provides a safe environment to measure system integrity.
*   The **Sequence of Tests** must be followed in a specific, logical order.

**Quick recap**
**Initial Verification** is the high-level process of ensuring a new installation is safe through a structured sequence. It begins with a **Visual Inspection** to find obvious faults and continues with a specific **Sequence of Tests** performed as **Dead Testing**. This ensures that every part of the system is verified in a logical, safe order before the power is ever turned on.

### Coming Up Next
Next, we will look at the specific safety thresholds and the mandatory procedures required to ensure the system is safe to touch during these tests.

content.title: Safety Thresholds
content.content:
### In this lesson
This lesson covers the critical safety protocols that must be established before any physical contact with a system occurs. You will learn the rigorous steps of safe isolation and how to identify conditions that require an immediate work stoppage. Key takeaways include the purpose of proving dead, the tools required for safe isolation, and identifying "stop-and-fix" triggers.

**What this is**
**Safe Isolation** is a mandatory procedure used to ensure electrical equipment is disconnected from the supply and secured against re-energisation, not just switched off. It involves a multi-step process: identifying the source, disconnecting it, locking it in the 'off' position, and placing a warning tag. The most critical part of this process is **Proving Dead**. This is the act of confirming the absence of voltage using a calibrated test lamp and proving unit, which is different from using a non-contact voltage detector. A non-contact detector (like a "voltage pen") is often unreliable and should not be used for safety-critical checks. To prove dead, you must test your lamp on a known live source (the proving unit), then test the circuit, then test the lamp on the proving unit again to confirm it is still working.

**Why it matters**
Failing to perform **Safe Isolation** can have fatal consequences. If a technician assumes a circuit is off because a switch is down, they risk encountering "back-feed" or someone else turning the power back on while they are working. **Proving Dead** provides a physical guarantee that the environment is safe. Beyond the procedural safety, a technician must also look for "stop-and-fix" triggers during their initial checks. These are visual indicators like charred components, exposed wires, or severe mechanical damage. If these are found, testing cannot proceed because the act of testing itself could be dangerous or yield useless data.

**Key facts / rules**
*   **Safe Isolation** requires a physical lock and a unique key held by the technician.
*   **Proving Dead** must be done with a dedicated test lamp and a proving unit.
*   The "Test-Point-Test" method (proving the tester before and after) is mandatory.
*   Visual indicators of heat or arcing are immediate grounds for a work stoppage.
*   A "dead" circuit must show a reading of zero volts; any other reading indicates a failure in isolation.
*   Safety signs and tags must be used to communicate the isolation status to others.

**How to do it**
To perform the procedure, first locate the point of isolation and switch it off. Secure the device with a lock and a "Do Not Operate" tag. Next, take your calibrated test lamp and check it against the proving unit; the lamp should illuminate to show it is functional. Then, apply the test lamp to the circuit conductors to confirm no voltage is present. Finally, re-check the test lamp against the proving unit. If the lamp fails to light up during the final check, you cannot assume the circuit was dead, and the process must be repeated with a working lamp. For example, if a technician finds a circuit reading 50V instead of 0V, they must stop immediately and trace the source of the stray voltage before touching any components.

**Common mistakes**
Learners often confuse **Proving Dead** with simply switching off; **Proving Dead** involves a verified physical check of voltage absence, whereas switching off only changes the state of a control device. Another mistake is using a non-contact voltage detector for safety verification, which is dangerous as these devices can give false negatives. 

Misconceptions (targeted):
* Misconception: A circuit is safe if the main switch is off and the lights went out. | Correction: You must perform **Safe Isolation** and **Proving Dead** to account for faulty switches or alternative power sources. | AC: AC2
* Misconception: If I find a broken enclosure, I can just test around it. | Correction: Obvious damage is a "stop-and-fix" trigger that requires repair before any **Dead Testing** can begin. | AC: AC3

**Key Points**
*   **Safe Isolation** prevents accidental re-energisation of the system.
*   **Proving Dead** requires a three-step check with a proving unit.
*   Non-contact voltage pens are not acceptable for proving dead.
*   Visual hazards like exposed conductors require an immediate work stoppage.

**Quick recap**
Safety in testing relies on two pillars: **Safe Isolation** and identifying unsafe conditions. By following the lock-tag-verify method and **Proving Dead** with a test lamp and proving unit, you ensure the system is truly de-energized. If you encounter significant damage during your **Visual Inspection**, you must stop and fix the issue before proceeding with the **Sequence of Tests**.

### Coming Up Next
In the next lesson, we will begin the first physical test in the sequence: checking the continuity of protective conductors.

This order is necessary because visual checks verify the physical integrity of the equipment, ensuring that the act of isolating or proving-dead does not trigger a fault or contact a live component.

expectedAnswer: The verification workflow begins with a visual inspection to identify work stoppage triggers, followed by a mandatory safe isolation procedure that includes proving the system is dead. These elements work together by ensuring that obvious physical hazards are corrected before the technician establishes an electrical safety threshold. By following this strict chronological sequence, the technician mitigates the risk of interacting with a live or faulty system during the subsequent testing phases.

• The process follows a mandatory sequence of visual inspection followed by physical dead testing.
• Work stoppage is triggered by any visual indicators of unsafe conditions or non-compliant installations.
• Proving-dead is the final step of safe isolation, confirming the safety threshold is active before testing.
• Together, these steps ensure that hazards are identified visually and confirmed electrically before any diagnostic work begins.
